moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3: I hate playing against the Sicilian defense as White, but once I open with P-K4, my opponent can force it on me.
moves.2... d6 3. d4: The best thing I can do is force a variation of the Sicilian which I feel is bad for Black. If I can play P-QB4, it will negate the effect of Black's opening move.
moves.4... Nf6 5. Bd3: By playing this move instead of 5 N-QB3, I preserve my ability...
moves.6... Bg7 7. Nc3: Now I can develop my Knight *behind* the Pawn.
moves.7... O-O 8. O-O: Both sides tuck their Kings away, and the middle game can begin even though development still needs to be finished.
moves.8... Nfd7 9. Bf4: Oops. 9 B-K3 was the correct move. i simply overlooked the fact my Knight was en prise.
moves.9... Bxd4 10. Nd5: Another oversight. 10 N-R4 guards the Pawn, which now falls.
moves.10... Bxb2 11. Rb1: I *did*, however, see that my Rook was attacked.
moves.11... Bd4 12. Qg4: Now that I'm down a piece and a Pawn, I have no choice but to launch an attack. Passive play will surely lose.
moves.12... Nc5 13. Qg3: Ducking out of the line of fire.
moves.13... Nxd3 14. Qxd3: I have to retake, of course. But every exchange is to my detriment, as it simplifies the position.
moves.14... Nc6 15. Rb3: I'm hoping to generate a K-side attack with the Q and R, in conjunction with my well posted Knight and Bishop.
moves.15... e5 16. Bh6: The beginnings of a plan. If I can get my Q to KB6... but the problem is that Black's Q is guarding that square.
moves.16... Re8 17. Qf3: I move the Q into position. But now what?
moves.17... Na5 18. Rd3: Must duck out of the way. It's now 4th and 26, and I'm down to one desperation play.
moves.18... Nxc4 19. Nf6+: And the pass is complete! I win the Rook, reestablishing material equality.
moves.19... Kh8 20. Nxe8: If Black doesn't retake, I simply retreat the Knight, having reestablished material equality. If Black does recapture...
moves.20... Qxe8 21. Qf6+: ...I gain access to the crucial square, and have a mate in 1. Black resigns.
